name: NPR
text: Most of the U.S. will "fall back" during Sunday's wee hours. Many sleep researchers say daylight saving time does more harm than good. https://t.co/aEb0lTeIJV

name: NPR
text:
If you've been on edge about the election, your kids have noticed. Because they're naturally self-centered, they'll assume your stress is about them.

Here's @NPRLifeKit's primer on how to talk with them about it: https://t.co/sXHrx2GPVt

name: NPR
text: England will enter a second coronavirus lockdown beginning on Thursday that is scheduled to run until early December, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said. https://t.co/3YeIO3Imrq

text: Duke anthropologist Brian Hare argues that humans unintentionally experienced a domestication process that left us more cooperative than our now-extinct human cousins, like Neanderthals and Denisovans. https://t.co/FNqBf8GOfy

name: NPR
text: Only days out from Election Day, control of the Senate remains a jump ball. These are the races that will decide it: https://t.co/MUPn6CxhsL

text: It's remarkable how many nasty ingredients go into making some of the most beautiful colors: bugs, urine, manure. But they're all on prismatic display at the Forbes Pigment Collection, a shrine to the building blocks of our most beloved works of art. https://t.co/P4E25UlqrJ

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: She offered to donate a kidney to her spouse. But doctors explained if they chose a kidney swap program, they might be able to help someone else, too; someone else might help them.

It set off an extraordinary chain of events, says @nprscottsimon. https://t.co/mJEwtU3EM6

name: NPR
text:
Texas Republicans have asked the courts to toss out some 127,000 early ballots cast in the Democratic-leaning Harris County. 

"This is simply an un-American attempt to disenfranchise voters," the Democratic county clerk said, calling the move "baseless." https://t.co/K3bmslcVTq

name: NPR
text: The effort is part of a widespread push by Republicans to reject new voter accommodation strategies implemented as the result of the coronavirus. https://t.co/78Jm1ASc4G

name: NPR
text:
The case of the Harris County ballots is set to be heard Monday morning.

U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen in Houston â€” seen as a deeply conservative federal magistrate â€” is set to rule over the complaint. https://t.co/XNnoTlbq6i

name: NPR
text:
Superlatives and exaggerations are an indulgence to which we all succumb. 

But as we contemplate "the most important election of our lives," let us acknowledge there will be legitimately extraordinary events.

Actual records will, in fact, be shattered. https://t.co/2sl8vOyBiw

text:
NPR will not report election results being tallied or projected by news outlets that are not The Associated Press. We rely on the AP in large part because it has a track record of precision and caution.
https://t.co/xDsXjaIs2M

name: NPR
text:
Typically, a hacker wants to go undetected. But it's also possible they want to get noticed â€” hoping the revelation will undermine public confidence in the election, even if they didn't access sensitive information.

Experts call that a "perception hack." https://t.co/P5uyeLQeCX

name: NPR
text:
Released Nov. 1, 1970,  "American Beauty" earned the Grateful Dead the title of the great American jam band.

Two of NPR's resident Deadheads â€” one who lived through the Dead's heyday; the other born after Jerry Garcia died â€” reflect on the album: https://t.co/HP86Eb7wA0

text:

name: NPR
text:
In a Kenyan fishing village, women fought the practice of fishermen demanding sex in exchange for fish to sell. They were making progress. Then came the catastrophic floods of 2020.

"The swelling of the lake has totally destroyed our lives." 
https://t.co/KV9vf1rTe5

name: NPR
text:
After vehicles with Trump 2020 flags boxed in their bus on a Texas highway, the Biden-Harris campaign canceled at least one event in the state.

At a rally, President Trump said his supporters had been "protecting" the bus "because they're nice." https://t.co/Uj93ZWGoF8

name: NPR
text:
